titleStmt.title: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Pennsylvania University Museum, E 16264 S

respStmt.resp: Edited by Michael Marx in collaboration with Tobias J. Jocham et. al. TEI version created by Yasmin Faghihi and Huw Jones

availability.p: Image credits: Courtesy of Pennsylvania University Museum Philadelphia.

summary.p: 1 fol. on parchment; Shelfmark: E 16264 S; Qurʾānic Text: Q 8:67-8:72, Q 8:75-9:3; 9 lines per page (orig. 21 lines); Dimensions: 73 x 60mm (orig. 150 x 120mm); Script style: kūfī B.II; Estimated date of production: 660-750 (?).
The catalogue of Arabic manuscripts kept by the University Museum in Philaldelphia, written by Giorgio Levi Della Vida gives the following information (Levi Della Vida 1981, p. 163):

"135. Inv. E. 16264 S. 3rd-4th century A. H./9th-10th century A. D. Yellowish, thin parchment. 6 x 7.3 cm. Lower middle part of a sheet, the original size of which must have been ca. 12 x 15 cm. Nine broken lines are written in a much faded brown ink on both faces (the original page must have contained twenty-one). The lower margin, 1.7 cm. wide, is partialy preserved. From the Ellen W. Harrison Collection. Recto: Koran 8,67 (68) [تريـ]ـدو[ن] – 72 (73) و[انفسهم]. Verso: 8,75 (76) [شـ]ـىء – 9,3 وبـ[ـشر]. The script is a small, archaic looking "Kūfic". Medial ḥāʾ (jīm, khāʾ), reversed final yāʾ, seperate medial ʿayn, final nūn and ṣād with little rounded loop, all point towards a rather old age. The bend of the end of the alifs is inconspicuous, and the script is straight. No diacritical signs and only scanty and faded off vowel marks appear on this fragment. A circle in black ink, surrouned by dots, appears on recto line 2 as verse divider after verse 67; however, it seems to have been added later (on the verso, some letters have been written over with the same ink), and no division marks appear after 8,70 (recto line 7) and 9,2 (verso line 5). Before sūra 9, the number of its verses is given in red: مائة وثلثون اية….. " ..... one hundred and thirty verses " (in agreement with all sources, except for the Cairo edition, which has 129: see A. Spitaler, Die Verszählung des Koran, p. 38)."
